reviews.review_msg:
The lecture has been recorded in advance, so you can study by yourself via his notes and slides. I didn't visit the school for this course all semester, but he gave one paper to read weekly, its very helpful to connect the course. He always replied to emails quickly and detailly, and He is generous with assignments extension.
Highly recommend!
Best prof in SFU Geog hands down. True gem. You learn so much and he knows so much it's fantastic. Never saw a teacher so actively engaged in everyone's learning. Fantastic.

His class was information heavy but truly inspiring and I actually learned so many things. He focuses on critical thinking NOT critical theory like 90%+ of other profs in the dep., so you actually learn multiple aspects and understand the complexity of the world. 100% would take again.

It's not even a writing class, and we have to write one short and one long paper for it. The worst thing is that for the short paper, he wants you to find articles online on a specific topic, but he won't tell you what articles. Basically, you are guessing, which takes too much time to do.

He's fine. His notes suck and he's completly scatered but it doesnt matter too much. He gives you literally 80% of the questions that will appear on the final beforehand so its not a big deal. Still got an A. Don't buy any texts. I never did the readings adn still got an A+.
He's a good lecturer and he outlines everything and makes even complex topics not that hard to understand. Exams were fair.. he even told us some of the possible questions in advance.
He is a nice prof but found him to be an inconsistent marker. Textbook is useless although he told us we would need it in the beginning of the term. As a lecturer he is okay.

Andrew is a great prof who expects a lot from his students but everything you learn is fairly valuable. It was his first time teaching the field school and he was very flexible and had endless field work for us (we didn't quite cover everything). 310 was by far the best course I have taken in my Environmental Science degree and would recommend.
